titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Herman Benson Papers TAM.834
titlestmt.author: Shannon O'Neill, Rachel Searcy

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-03 13:42:18 -0400.

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

did.abstract: Herman Benson (1915-2020) was a machinist, labor organizer, union reformer, and one of the co-founders of the Association for Union Democracy (AUD). Benson, a life-long New Yorker, recognized that even democratic entities like organized labor and unions wrestled with accountability and corruption. He is well-known for his work to introduce democratic reforms to trade unions. In 1969 he co-founded the AUD and he became the editor for the AUD's newsletter Union Democracy Review. From their website, AUD is "the only national, pro-labor, non-profit organization dedicated solely to advancing the principles and practices of democratic trade unionism in the North American labor movement. It is the premise of AUD that internal democracy makes unions stronger and better able to fight for the rights and interests of working people." AUD is notable for its non-partisan positioning, and as such does not endorse candidates for union positions or specific policies within unions. The organization works to empower union members by focusing on active participation, strengthening the democratic process, and free speech and fair elections. The Herman Benson Papers (dated 1933-2009) consist of materials created and collected by Benson documenting his work with the Association for Union Democracy (AUD), as well his life-long study of labor, socialism, alternatives to capitalism, and democratic causes. Materials include notebooks, research notes, and original writings in various stages of completion. Some notebooks also include observations on a wide variety of topics, similar to a journal or a scrapbook. The collection also includes correspondence and photographs. In addition to documenting Benson's involvement with AUD, the materials in this collection more directly document his intellectual process and his study of labor, labor movements, unions, labor organizing, and socialism.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please request materials at least two business days prior to your research visit to coordinate access.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Herman Benson Papers (dated 1933-2009) consist of materials created and collected by Benson documenting his work with the Association for Union Democracy (AUD), as well his life-long study of labor, socialism, alternatives to capitalism, and democratic causes. Materials include notebooks, research notes, and original writings in various stages of completion. Some notebooks also include observations on a wide variety of topics, similar to a journal or a scrapbook. The collection also includes correspondence and photographs. In addition to documenting Benson's involvement with AUD, the materials in this collection more directly document his intellectual process and his study of labor, labor movements, unions, labor organizing, and socialism.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: This collection is protected by copyright and/or related rights. You are free to use materials in the collection in any way that is permitted by the copyright and related rights legislation that applies to your use. For other uses you need to obtain permission from the rights-holder(s).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from the Association of Union Democracy in May 2024; the accession number associated with this purchase is 2024.029.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Herman Benson Papers; TAM 834; box number; folder number or item identifier; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: At the time of accessioning materials were rehoused in archival boxes, described on the collection-level, and inventoried on the folder-level.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Herman Benson (1915-2020) was a machinist, labor organizer, union reformer, and one of the co-founders of the Association for Union Democracy (AUD). Benson, a life-long New Yorker, recognized that even democratic entities like organized labor and unions wrestled with accountability and corruption. He is well-known for his work to introduce democratic reforms to trade unions. In 1969 he co-founded the AUD and he became the editor for the AUD's newsletter Union Democracy Review.

From their website, AUD is "the only national, pro-labor, non-profit organization dedicated solely to advancing the principles and practices of democratic trade unionism in the North American labor movement. It is the premise of AUD that internal democracy makes unions stronger and better able to fight for the rights and interests of working people." AUD is notable for its non-partisan positioning, and as such does not endorse candidates for union positions or specific policies within unions. The organization focuses its attention on empowering union members through active participation, strengthening the democratic process, and free speech and fair elections.
Association for Union Democracy. "About Us." Accessed May 31, 2024. https://uniondemocracy.org/about-us/
